_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: stationary ammonia tank, pump, and associated plumbing.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
Gavilon Fertilizer, LLC
401 Boyer Valley Rd., Denison, IA.

I.    The Facility Policy:

The Facility owner, management, and employees of Gavilon Fertilizer, LLC are 
committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Local 
responders are encouraged to visit the Facility to gain first hand knowledge of the site. 
Employees are required to hold monthly safety meeting and include sections of the 
management plan in those meetings. The facility maintains an internal emergency 
contingency plan.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work 
with local fire departments, and other authorities to mitigate any release, and to minimize 
the impact of a release on the population and environment.

II.   Facility Information:

The primary activity of the Facility is to distribute agricultural fertilizer for the farming 
industry in the area.  Part of the fertilizer comes in the form of Anhydrous Ammonia, 
here after referred to as ammonia.  Ammonia is received, stored, and used in the 
production of non-hazardous liquid fertilizer solutions. Ammonia is an important source 
of Nitrogen for agricultural crops during the spring and fall of the year.
 
The maximum quantity that can be stored at the facility is approximately 48,000 pounds.  The typical 
method of receiving ammonia is by truck transport containing 40,000 pounds. The 
transports are unloaded into the stationary storage tank.  A pump transfers the ammonia 
to the batch process. Batch process is not continuous but is operated intermittently. 

III.  Accidental Release Prevention:
   
The Facility takes guidance from material published by the American National Standards  
Institute Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia 
K61.1, and Compressed Gas Association CGA G-2 for design, construction, and 
maintenance of the process equipment.  The Facility also has a Proce

ss Safety Program 
that dovetails the RMP. The Facility tries to minimize the amount of ammonia held or 
stored at the facility through management judgment. Employees involved with the 
handling and processing are trained in their duties. The Facility continues to review and 
look for means to improve operating and Best management Practices for increase safety. 

IV. The Five-Year Accident History:
       
There have been no accidental releases of ammonia related to the operation of this facility 
in the past five years.  There have been no deaths, injuries, or significant property damage 
at the Facility.  
         
To the best of our knowledge, no off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, 
property  damage or environmental damage has occurred due to the operation of this 
facility.







Bibliography / References:
Technical Inc. prepared for NIOSH, HAZOP of  Anhydrous Ammonia Use in 
Agricultural 1991.

Clements Associates, Inc., Fairfax, VA;  Health Effects for Ammonia, prepared for The 
Fertilizer Institute.

U.S. Environmental Protection Agency  Chemical Emergency Preparedness and 
Prevention Advisory A¿ Ammonia, September 1991 Oswer 91-008.2, Series 8; No.2.

Ecology and Environment, Inc.,  Generic Hazard Assessment and Off-site 
Consequences Analysis Kern and Kings Counties' prepared for California Fertilizer 
Assoc. October 1990

American National Standard Institute, Inc., American National Standard Safety 
Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia  (K-61.1) March 
1989
